methods.name: pub const fn min_value() -> u16

description: Returns the smallest value that can be represented by this integer type.

methods.name: pub const fn max_value() -> u16

description: Returns the largest value that can be represented by this integer type.

methods.name: pub fn from_str_radix(src: &str, radix: u32) -> Result<u16, ParseIntError>

description: Converts a string slice in a given base to an integer.
The string is expected to be an optional + sign followed by digits. Leading and trailing whitespace represent an error. Digits are a subset of these characters, depending on radix:
0-9 a-z A-Z
Panics
This function panics if radix is not in the range from 2 to 36.

methods.name: pub const fn count_ones(self) -> u32

description: Returns the number of ones in the binary representation of self.

methods.name: pub const fn count_zeros(self) -> u32

description: Returns the number of zeros in the binary representation of self.

methods.name: pub const fn leading_zeros(self) -> u32

description: Returns the number of leading zeros in the binary representation of self.

methods.name: pub const fn trailing_zeros(self) -> u32

description: Returns the number of trailing zeros in the binary representation of self.

methods.name: pub const fn rotate_left(self, n: u32) -> u16

description: Shifts the bits to the left by a specified amount, n, wrapping the truncated bits to the end of the resulting integer.
Please note this isn't the same operation as <<!

methods.name: pub const fn rotate_right(self, n: u32) -> u16

description: Shifts the bits to the right by a specified amount, n, wrapping the truncated bits to the beginning of the resulting integer.
Please note this isn't the same operation as >>!

methods.name: pub const fn swap_bytes(self) -> u16

description: Reverses the byte order of the integer.

methods.name: pub const fn reverse_bits(self) -> u16
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (reverse_bits #48763)

methods.name: pub const fn from_be(x: u16) -> u16

description: Converts an integer from big endian to the target's endianness.
On big endian this is a no-op. On little endian the bytes are swapped.

methods.name: pub const fn from_le(x: u16) -> u16

description: Converts an integer from little endian to the target's endianness.
On little endian this is a no-op. On big endian the bytes are swapped.

methods.name: pub const fn to_be(self) -> u16

description: Converts self to big endian from the target's endianness.
On big endian this is a no-op. On little endian the bytes are swapped.

methods.name: pub const fn to_le(self) -> u16

description: Converts self to little endian from the target's endianness.
On little endian this is a no-op. On big endian the bytes are swapped.

methods.name: pub fn checked_add(self, rhs: u16) -> Option<u16>

description: Checked integer addition. Computes self + rhs, returning None if overflow occurred.

methods.name: pub fn checked_sub(self, rhs: u16) -> Option<u16>

description: Checked integer subtraction. Computes self - rhs, returning None if overflow occurred.

methods.name: pub fn checked_mul(self, rhs: u16) -> Option<u16>

description: Checked integer multiplication. Computes self * rhs, returning None if overflow occurred.

methods.name: pub fn checked_div(self, rhs: u16) -> Option<u16>

description: Checked integer division. Computes self / rhs, returning None if rhs == 0.

methods.name: pub fn checked_div_euc(self, rhs: u16) -> Option<u16>
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn checked_rem(self, rhs: u16) -> Option<u16>

description: Checked integer remainder. Computes self % rhs, returning None if rhs == 0.

methods.name: pub fn checked_mod_euc(self, rhs: u16) -> Option<u16>
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn checked_neg(self) -> Option<u16>

description: Checked negation. Computes -self, returning None unless self == 0.
Note that negating any positive integer will overflow.

methods.name: pub fn checked_shl(self, rhs: u32) -> Option<u16>

description: Checked shift left. Computes self << rhs, returning None if rhs is larger than or equal to the number of bits in self.

methods.name: pub fn checked_shr(self, rhs: u32) -> Option<u16>

description: Checked shift right. Computes self >> rhs, returning None if rhs is larger than or equal to the number of bits in self.

methods.name: pub fn checked_pow(self, exp: u32) -> Option<u16>
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (no_panic_pow #48320)

methods.name: pub fn saturating_add(self, rhs: u16) -> u16

description: Saturating integer addition. Computes self + rhs, saturating at the numeric bounds instead of overflowing.

methods.name: pub fn saturating_sub(self, rhs: u16) -> u16

description: Saturating integer subtraction. Computes self - rhs, saturating at the numeric bounds instead of overflowing.

methods.name: pub fn saturating_mul(self, rhs: u16) -> u16

description: Saturating integer multiplication. Computes self * rhs, saturating at the numeric bounds instead of overflowing.

methods.name: pub fn saturating_pow(self, exp: u32) -> u16
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (no_panic_pow #48320)

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_add(self, rhs: u16) -> u16

description: Wrapping (modular) addition. Computes self + rhs, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_sub(self, rhs: u16) -> u16

description: Wrapping (modular) subtraction. Computes self - rhs, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_mul(self, rhs: u16) -> u16

description: Wrapping (modular) multiplication. Computes self * rhs, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.
example:
Please note that this example is shared between integer types.
Which explains why u8 is used here.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_div(self, rhs: u16) -> u16

description: Wrapping (modular) division. Computes self / rhs. Wrapped division on unsigned types is just normal division. There's no way wrapping could ever happen. This function exists, so that all operations are accounted for in the wrapping operations.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_div_euc(self, rhs: u16) -> u16
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_rem(self, rhs: u16) -> u16

description: Wrapping (modular) remainder. Computes self % rhs. Wrapped remainder calculation on unsigned types is just the regular remainder calculation. There's no way wrapping could ever happen. This function exists, so that all operations are accounted for in the wrapping operations.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_mod_euc(self, rhs: u16) -> u16
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_neg(self) -> u16

description: Wrapping (modular) negation. Computes -self, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

Since unsigned types do not have negative equivalents all applications of this function will wrap (except for -0). For values smaller than the corresponding signed type's maximum the result is the same as casting the corresponding signed value. Any larger values are equivalent to MAX + 1 - (val - MAX - 1) where MAX is the corresponding signed type's maximum.
example:
Please note that this example is shared between integer types.
Which explains why i8 is used here.

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_shl(self, rhs: u32) -> u16

description: Panic-free bitwise shift-left; yields self << mask(rhs), where mask removes any high-order bits of rhs that would cause the shift to exceed the bitwidth of the type.

Note that this is not the same as a rotate-left; the RHS of a wrapping shift-left is restricted to the range of the type, rather than the bits shifted out of the LHS being returned to the other end. The primitive integer types all implement a rotate_left function, which may be what you want instead.

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_shr(self, rhs: u32) -> u16

description: Panic-free bitwise shift-right; yields self >> mask(rhs), where mask removes any high-order bits of rhs that would cause the shift to exceed the bitwidth of the type.

Note that this is not the same as a rotate-right; the RHS of a wrapping shift-right is restricted to the range of the type, rather than the bits shifted out of the LHS being returned to the other end. The primitive integer types all implement a rotate_right function, which may be what you want instead.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_pow(self, exp: u32) -> u16
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (no_panic_pow #48320)

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_add(self, rhs: u16) -> (u16, bool)

description: Calculates self + rhs
Returns a tuple of the addition along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. If an overflow would have occurred then the wrapped value is returned.

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_sub(self, rhs: u16) -> (u16, bool)

description: Calculates self - rhs
Returns a tuple of the subtraction along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. If an overflow would have occurred then the wrapped value is returned.

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_mul(self, rhs: u16) -> (u16, bool)

description: Calculates the multiplication of self and rhs.
Returns a tuple of the multiplication along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. If an overflow would have occurred then the wrapped value is returned.
example:
Please note that this example is shared between integer types.
Which explains why u32 is used here.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_div(self, rhs: u16) -> (u16, bool)

description: Calculates the divisor when self is divided by rhs.
Returns a tuple of the divisor along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. Note that for unsigned integers overflow never occurs, so the second value is always false.
Panics
This function will panic if rhs is 0.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_div_euc(self, rhs: u16) -> (u16, bool)
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_rem(self, rhs: u16) -> (u16, bool)

description: Calculates the remainder when self is divided by rhs.

Returns a tuple of the remainder after dividing along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. Note that for unsigned integers overflow never occurs, so the second value is always false.
Panics
This function will panic if rhs is 0.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_mod_euc(self, rhs: u16) -> (u16, bool)
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_neg(self) -> (u16, bool)

description: Negates self in an overflowing fashion.

Returns !self + 1 using wrapping operations to return the value that represents the negation of this unsigned value. Note that for positive unsigned values overflow always occurs, but negating 0 does not overflow.
example:
assert_eq!(0u16.overflowing_neg(), (0, false));
assert_eq!(2u16.overflowing_neg(), (-2i32 as u16, true));

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_shl(self, rhs: u32) -> (u16, bool)

description: Shifts self left by rhs bits.

Returns a tuple of the shifted version of self along with a boolean indicating whether the shift value was larger than or equal to the number of bits. If the shift value is too large, then value is masked (N-1) where N is the number of bits, and this value is then used to perform the shift.

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_shr(self, rhs: u32) -> (u16, bool)

description: Shifts self right by rhs bits.

Returns a tuple of the shifted version of self along with a boolean indicating whether the shift value was larger than or equal to the number of bits. If the shift value is too large, then value is masked (N-1) where N is the number of bits, and this value is then used to perform the shift.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_pow(self, exp: u32) -> (u16, bool)
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (no_panic_pow #48320)

methods.name: pub fn pow(self, exp: u32) -> u16

description: Raises self to the power of exp, using exponentiation by squaring.

methods.name: pub fn div_euc(self, rhs: u16) -> u16
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn mod_euc(self, rhs: u16) -> u16
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn is_power_of_two(self) -> bool

description: Returns true if and only if self == 2^k for some k.

methods.name: pub fn next_power_of_two(self) -> u16

description: Returns the smallest power of two greater than or equal to self.
When return value overflows (i.e. self > (1 << (N-1)) for type uN), it panics in debug mode and return value is wrapped to 0 in release mode (the only situation in which method can return 0).

methods.name: pub fn checked_next_power_of_two(self) -> Option<u16>

description: Returns the smallest power of two greater than or equal to n. If the next power of two is greater than the type's maximum value, None is returned, otherwise the power of two is wrapped in Some.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_next_power_of_two(self) -> u16
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (wrapping_next_power_of_two #32463)needs decision on wrapping behaviour
